Is exercise better than other treatments, such as injections, or surgery, for improving pain and function in people with patellar tendinopathy (a condition that causes knee pain due to tendon problems)?

We are very uncertain whether strengthening exercise reduces pain compared to no treatment, glucocorticoid injection, or surgery for people with patellar tendinopathy. 
- Strengthening exercise may make little or no difference to function compared to no treatment, glucocorticoid injection, or surgery, but the current evidence does not allow us to say this with confidence, partly because most studies were in athletes and not the general public.
- Future research should focus on comparing exercise to other treatments with longer follow-up periods and in more diverse groups of people, including non-athletes, to better understand the benefits and potential harms of different treatments for patellar tendinopathy.

What is patellar tendinopathy and why is it a problem?
Patellar tendinopathy is a common condition that affects the tendon (a tissue that connects muscles to bones) at the front of the knee, causing pain. It is a prevalent problem, particularly among athletes, and can impact daily activities and sports performance. The main treatment for patellar tendinopathy involves different types of exercise, such as strengthening (making muscles stronger) and stretching (making muscles more flexible), as well as other treatments like surgery and glucocorticoid injections (a type of steroid injection).

What did the review authors want to find out?
The review authors aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of exercise for the treatment of patellar tendinopathy. They wanted to find out whether strengthening exercise reduces pain and improves function compared to no treatment, glucocorticoid injection, or surgery, and to assess the certainty of the evidence for these outcomes.

What did we find?
We found 7 studies that involved 211 people with chronic patellar tendinopathy. The studies were conducted in various settings and included athletes with a mean age of 26 years and a mean duration of symptoms of 41.6 months. Most studies compared strengthening exercises with no treatment, glucocorticoid injection, surgery, stretching exercise, or pulsed ultrasound and transverse friction. We did not find any studies that compared exercise with placebo or sham intervention. Strengthening exercise may make little or no difference to pain and function compared to no treatment, glucocorticoid injection, or surgery. It is unclear if strengthening exercise has an effect on treatment success and return to sport. We do not know if strengthening exercise has an effect on quality of life and adverse events.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
We found that all trials were small, making the evidence very uncertain. Participants were likely aware of their assigned treatment, introducing performance bias. These limitations apply to comparisons of strengthening exercise versus no treatment, glucocorticoid injection, and surgery.

How up-to-date is the evidence?
The evidence is up to date to September 2023.
